PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Rationale  East  Timor's  transport  and  power  infrastructure  was  severely 
damaged during the postreferendum conflict and was unable to 
facilitate  humanitarian  relief  or  security  operations.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  prepared  and  administered  a  grant 
funded  by  the  Trust  Fund  for  East  Timor  (TFET)  for  the 
Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (EIRP) to restore 
road  conditions,  port  operations,  and  power  supply  to  enable 
humanitarian aid delivery and resumption of economic activities. 
The needs of the infrastructure sectors, particularly for road sector 
restoration, require additional funding over and above the initial 
grant.  Supplementary  resources  for  the  EIRP  are  to  support 
restoration of the road conditions to a standard where the road 
network can make a contribution to economic activities and be 
maintained by an East Timorese field maintenance administration.

maintenance operation in East Timor.

I.  THE PROJECT 
1.  I submit for your information the following report on a supplementary grant to East Timor 
for  the  Emergency  Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  Project  (Phase  2)  (EIRP-2).1  The  project 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  INTRODUCTION 
2.  In January 2000, the United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) 
asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare and administer emergency assistance to 
rehabilitate damaged infrastructure for early restoration of normal socioeconomic activities. An 
ADB  appraisal  mission2  visited  East  Timor  in  February  2000  and  prepared  the  EIRP.3 
Negotiations for the Grant Agreement for the Project were completed with UNTAET on 29 March 
2000, and became effective on 19 April 2000. Funding for the grant is drawn from the Trust Fund 
for  East  Timor  (TFET),  which  is  established  under  the  trusteeship  of  the  International 
Development  Agency  of  the  World  Bank  Group.  The  TFET  does  not  include  ADB’s  own 
resources. Implementation of the EIRP commenced in late April and disbursements in May 2000.  
 
3.  The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  began  operations  in  April  2000  with  both 
international and East Timorese staff. In May 2000, the PMU issued the first work orders to 
repair the worst road closures. In June, five major contracts were implemented on the main road 
sections to facilitate road access during the rainy season in the third quarter of 2000. Since then 
a  total  of  66  road  rehabilitation  contracts,  involving  a  significant  share  of  East  Timorese 
contractors and consultants, have been awarded under the EIRP. The impact of these works 
has been significant in facilitating humanitarian aid to rural areas and enhancing the revival of 
economic activities since the September 1999 crisis. 
 
4.  In  August  2000,  the  EIRP  completed  upgrading  a  container  terminal  yard  and  an 
incomplete third berth, and repaired a landing slip at Dili Port. These actions have reduced 
congestion of port premises and contributed to reducing vessel queuing time, thus enhancing 
delivery of goods and aid. Also in August 2000, the 21 rural power stations assigned to the 
EIRP were assessed. Work on the power station was delayed due to the gradual award of 
disbursement authority resulting from delayed cash receipts in the TFET and poor security 
conditions along the western border of East Timor. The rehabilitation works are now estimated 
to require $2.4 million, and a difficult prioritization process has been carried out to adjust the 
work program to the available funding.  
 
5.  The infrastructure sectors, and most pressingly roads, suffer from immediate needs that 
require funding beyond the EIRP and the limited bilateral resources. Additional funding of $9.0 
million has become available from the TFET for the infrastructure sectors. UNTAET asked ADB 
to prepare the project documentation for and administer implementation of the new allocation. 
Subsequently, appraisal was carried out from 14 to 28 February 2001.4 Objectives, scope, and 
implementation  were  agreed  in  a  memorandum  of  understanding.  In  light  of  the  limited 
availability of additional funding, the sector needs have been considered under a rigorous

III.  BACKGROUND 
A.  Response to Crisis 
6.  Description of Damage. In the democratic consultation of 30 August 1999, the people 
of East Timor voted overwhelmingly for independence. This was followed by a campaign of 
destruction, during which three quarters of the population fled their homes and most of the 
country’s infrastructure, commerce, and private homes were destroyed. Most of the refugees 
have now returned from West Timor and the forest, and have settled with the support of 
humanitarian relief. Consequent to the postreferendum destruction, all administrative structures 
became dysfunctional, including public offices tasked to manage the infrastructure sectors.  
 
7.  Administration.  A  resolution  of  the  United  Nations  Security  Council  established 
UNTAET to ensure stability and establish a transitional government prior to formation of an East 
Timorese administration. General elections were conducted on 30 August 2001, and an East 
Timorese  Second  Transitional  Administration  through  its  cabinet  of  members  assumed 
responsibility for economic development as delegated under UNTAET Regulation No. 2001/28. 
UNTAET administered East Timor until 19 May 2002. On 20 May 2002, East Timor gained its 
independence and is now governed as a republic with a democratically elected president and 
parliament, and a prime minister-led government. Under its Resolution No. 1412 of 17 May 
2002, the Security Council established a United Nations Mission in East Timor to support the 
core administrative structures critical to the viability and political stability of East Timor. In 
September  2001,  the  former  Department  of  Infrastructure  that  had  managed 
telecommunications, postal services, electricity, water and sanitation, and transport, including 
roads, ports, and aviation, was replaced by the Ministry of Water and Public Works (MWPW) 
responsible for roads, water, buildings and the Government's civil works and the Ministry of 
Communications and Transport responsible for ports, airports and land transport. 
 
8.  Recurrent Budget. The Government's recurrent budget is drawn from donor funding. 
Expenditures are primarily salaries for East Timorese employees and recurrent consumables 
such as fuel. The capital development budget, drawn from the TFET, was assessed by a World 
Bank-coordinated multiagency joint assessment mission (JAM) in October-November 1999. 
Comprehensive  sector  budgets,  prepared  with  ADB  support,  reflect  significant  shortfalls 
between the needs and trust fund contributions in the recurrent and capital budgets.  
 
9.  Poverty. East Timor’s poverty profile is dramatically affected by the massive political, 
economic, and social upheaval in September 1999.6 As a result of the postreferendum violence, 
cash incomes became nonexistent for most of the population. In 1996, when East Timor was 
part of Indonesia, its gross domestic product (GDP) per capita income was $431, or 37% of the

10.  Restoration  Programs.  In  response  to  the  crisis,  the  United  Nations  Office  for 
Coordination  of  Humanitarian  Affairs  coordinated  immediate  humanitarian  relief  programs

result, ADB and the World Bank agreed to work together on the reconstruction of East Timor, 
with ADB as the lead agency for restoring the infrastructure sectors. Subsequently, ADB's Board 
approved  a  delegated  approval  authority  for  project  proposals  by  ADB's  Management, 
expanded  eligibility  under  ADB's  procurement  guidelines,  disbursement  procedures  in 
accordance with ADB's disbursement guidelines, and establishment of grant agreements for 
projects funded from the TFET (footnote 5).7 
 
11.  The ADB-funded technical assistance (TA) for transport sector restoration8 implemented 
ADB’s  first  intervention  in  the  three  transport  subsectors  by  taking  steps  to  establish  the 
institutions  and  regulatory  frameworks  in  the  road,  port,  and  airport  subsectors,  and  by 
reviewing the long-term development requirements. Further TA will be implemented to prepare 
legal frameworks for the new institutions and implement effective agency operations. The TAs 
and the EIRP work in tandem to support the process for establishing appropriately scaled sector 
operations in East Timor.  
 
B.  Transport Subsector Description 
12.  East Timor forms the eastern half of Timor Island, and includes the islands of Atauro and 
Joco and the Oecusse enclave, on the north coast of the island within Indonesian territory. It 
stretches for 250 kilometers (km) east to west and 80 km north to south at the widest point with 
an area of 14,900 square kilometers (km2).9 The terrain is dominated by a spinal range of 
mountains reaching nearly 3,000 meters (m) at the highest point. Narrow plains characterize the 
north and south coasts. The hinterland consists mainly of mountains and intervening narrow 
valleys, which become broader and flatter in the east with extensive limestone plateaus.  
 
13.  The transport system in East Timor is multimodal, comprising about 5,000 km of roads; 
one container port, three smaller wharves, small jetties, and landings; and two international 
airports and eight grass airstrips. The past demand on the transport system in East Timor was 
that of a provincial economy. All internal traffic in East Timor depended on land transport, 
awarding the road sector a paramount role. Benefits from intermodal linkages are minimal as 
domestic maritime transport is not available, and the potential for inland and southern coastal

1.  Roads 
a.  Description 
14.  The road network is supported by the main coastal east-west arteries along the northern 
and southern coastlines. The north-south secondary roads connect these two links. The network 
consists of some 1,200 km of main roads, 2,000 km of district roads, and about 1,800 km of 
feeder roads. The road network is relatively dense considering the low level of economic 
development and sparse population with approximately 1 km of road for 3 km2; about 50% of 
roads were sealed at one time. 
 
15.  However, this network is challenged by young geology and weather conditions. Forty 
percent of the land is on steep slopes. The tectonic conditions of the island endow it with 
sedimentary sandstone and calcareous rocks with some basic igneous material; these rocks 
comprise conglomerates; reef limestone; and alluvial cobble, sand, and silt deposits. From an 
engineering viewpoint, these conditions and the lightweight nature of the pavement require 
annual maintenance action. As a result, roads remain fragile and susceptible to a monsoon 
climate  that  even  under  the  best  conditions  would  require  a  moderate  to  high  level  of 
maintenance.  From  an  engineering  viewpoint,  the  geology  even  without  earthworks  or 
agriculture makes roads highly susceptible to severe annual landslides. Many routes are also 
crossed by a number of large braided rivers10 with a combination of bridges and causeways. 
These causeways are vulnerable to the natural realignment of the waterways. During the rainy 
season, rivers flood the roads and interrupt the transport system.  
 
16.  While most of the main road network was sealed, the road surfaces on the minor 
network have now deteriorated to gravel. The sealed network was built to a minimum standard 
to provide all-weather access to small and light vehicle traffic. The lightweight nature of the 
pavement has not been viable, and could only be so if kept well drained and vehicle axle loads 
restricted.  Although  the  Indonesian  Government  spent  most  public  funds  on  infrastructure, 
infrastructure systems in East Timor remained underdeveloped. Road repairs and maintenance 
were inadequately funded. Eighty percent of the 1997/98 infrastructure budget of $5.8 million, 
funded both centrally and locally, implemented roadworks in East Timor. In the following year, 
this was reduced by 22%, with the road improvement budget falling by 25%, road rehabilitation 
by 65%, and maintenance by 14%.  
 
17.  All roads have suffered from the long-term neglect of maintenance. The maintenance 
challenge was compounded by the low design standard adopted and the changing course of the 
many north-south braided rivers. The roads, built for low volumes and light traffic, and then used 
by  the  heavy  vehicles  of  the  transitional  administration,  have  deteriorated  further.  As  a 
consequence, the network has incurred a large backlog of road repair needs in addition to 
ordinary routine maintenance. While the EIRP is addressing the backlog requirement, if the 
network is to be left in a reasonable and maintainable condition at project completion, additional

b.  Medium- to Long-Term Sector Development  
18.  Economic Context. The road network is an extremely valuable asset for East Timor. 
Given the foreseeable economic circumstances of the country, an extensively paved national 
road network is an irreplaceable national endowment that could be irreparably damaged if 
regular maintenance is not instituted as a matter of urgency. GDP growth in East Timor is 
projected11 until 2003 at 15% per annum as a result of reconstruction. From 2004 to 2010, the 
annual GDP growth rate is forecast at 10% due to the impact of full production from the Timor 
Gap oil fields. Growth is projected to stabilize at 7% from 2011 to 2015 and at 5% from 2015 to 
2030.  The  growth  drivers—agricultural  production,  crops,  and  livestock—need  transport 
services. Traffic for forestry, fishing, tourism, other service activities, and microenterprises will 
grow in direct proportion to the growth drivers. Only with adequate accessibility will production 
activities  diversify  and  intensify  and  the  benefits  of  increased  productivity,  employment, 
population, and per capita income will follow. 
 
19.  Transport  Sector  Plan.  The  role  of  a  sound  transport  sector  plan  is  central  for 
identification of the transport sector linkages with the productive sectors and macroeconomic 
development,  sector  management,  operation  and  maintenance,  intermodal  planning,  and 
cohesive investment programs and work plans. A draft multimodal transport sector plan was 
prepared under the Transport Sector Restoration TA (footnote 8) for the consideration of the 
new government as a national transport plan.  
 
20.  Sector Administration. The transport subsectors are currently managed by MWPW by 
a minister and a vice-minister. These are supported by a director general and a small staff. The 
low levels of East Timorese staff have constrained the capacity building process. In July 2000, 
the National Cabinet of East Timor approved the drafting of a transport act to provide for the 
establishment of ports, airports, and road under one legislative instrument. The advantages of 
one legal instrument are clarity and ability to extract all economies of scale in organizing sector 
administration. Legal and structural establishment of transport sector administration is pending. 
UNTAET requested ADB-funded TA to (i) draft legislation and (ii) support implementation of 
efficient organizations that would be directly accountability to the government and users for 
policy and strategy implementation for service provision, and management efficiency. TA for 
Transport Sector Improvement was approved on 1 October 200112 for this purpose. 
 
21.  Requirements. The road budget in Appendix 2 provides a view of the requirements for a 
basic road service. This service level facilitates access to most villages, delivery of minimal 
social services, and transport needs of agricultural produce to the main markets. The budget 
also records currently available funding for roads. With the EIRP-2 and the EIRP successfully 
reducing the backlog maintenance requirement to a minimum, maintaining 1,200 km of the total 
of 5,000 km of roads in their current condition is estimated to cost about $9.3 million per annum. 
This figure comprises road agency costs of $3.4 million, and routine and emergency monsoon 
maintenance costs of $4.4 million and $1.5 million.

22.  Funding. Facing a constrained road budget, the road agency may consider funding 
periodic road and bridge maintenance through carefully targeted investment projects until the 
road subsector can recover financing from its client users. These estimates assume that the 
current grant-funded programs will hand the network over to the new road administration free of 
an  accumulated  backlog  maintenance  requirement.  The  addition  of  periodic  maintenance 
activity—pavement  repair,  regraveling,  resurfacing  sealed  pavements—would  increase  the 
annual road maintenance budget to an unaffordable $20 million. The road budget represents 
about 4% of the total recurrent budget of $63.5 million of the Government. This remains below 
the average road sector expenditure in most countries. The UNTAET allocated $2.3 million with 
a total of $13.7 million coming from the TFET and the Government of Japan in the 2001/02 
fiscal year; $7.0 million in 2002/03, $15 million in 2003/04, and $18 million in 2004/05. These 
figures correspond with calculated maintenance needs. Excluding the promise provided by the 
off-shore gas economy, the total recurrent budget is sustainable, in particular with the planned 
budgetary support from the World Bank. 
 
23.  Road Assets. The EIRP is preparing a detailed road asset inventory and condition 
database, crucial for establishing an optimal road maintenance regime. Based on this data, a 
reclassification of the roads to their functional categories based on traffic and use will support 
rationalizing road maintenance resources with the priority requirements.  
 
24.  Road Maintenance. An adequate recurrent budget will prevent deterioration of social 
conditions, isolation of villages, and significant reduction in access to social services including 
access  to  schools,  health  clinics,  electricity,  and  water.  Establishing  a  cost-effective  road 
maintenance regime requires foresight to finance recurrent routine and preventive maintenance, 
and thus budget discipline, determination, and a change to a systematic maintenance mentality. 
These  must  be  effectively  maintained  by  establishing  an  appropriately  scaled  routine 
maintenance program and administration. To ensure such affordability, reduction of the backlog 
maintenance  requirement  is  the  objective  of  the  ongoing  emergency  road  repair  and 
rehabilitation  programs.  While  the  EIRP  addresses  the  accumulated  backlog,  additional 
resources are required for to bring the road network to a maintainable condition, in which it can 
be managed by the new maintenance regime. With the supplementary funding, the restoration 
program is expected to reduce the backlog requirement and thus enable road maintenance with 
a minimal budget. Concurrently, the EIRP is establishing technical capacity within the field 
organization  to  deliver  routine,  emergency,  and  periodic  maintenance  services.  Additional 
resources are required to endow the field organization with the technical skills, management 
process, and contractual regime with which it will be able to maintain the repaired network.  
 
C.  External Assistance and Donor Coordination 
25.  The EIRP is fully coordinated with donor support to the overall emergency restoration of 
East Timor, and in particular, with the emergency programs in the three project sectors. The 
EIRP  has  cofinanced  and  collaborated  in  civil  works  programs  of  the  United  Nations 
Peacekeeping  Force  (UNPKF).  Particularly  in  river  training,  UNPKF  equipment  has  been 
deployed in combination with community labor engaged by the EIRP to enhance water flow in 
the original river channel and to facilitate labor-based road repairs.

IV.  THE EMERGENCY INFRASTRUCTURE REHABILITATION PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
26.  The EIRP has aimed to support humanitarian assistance in East Timor by rehabilitating 
transport and power infrastructure to facilitate peace and security, and to provide the East 
Timorese with access to the humanitarian relief aid. 
 
B.  Objectives and Scope 
27.  The EIRP objective is to (i) undertake emergency road repair works to facilitate efficient 
transport of humanitarian aid and security cargo, and to induce revival of economic activity; (ii) 
expand the capacity of port facilities to reduce congestion; and (iii) reinstate power supply. In 
addition  to  its  emergency  nature,  the  EIRP  supports  long-term  sector  development  by 
strengthening the local contracting industry, instituting operational and maintenance systems, 
and providing capacity building for sector management. 
  
28.  The EIRP consists of the following components: 
 
(i)  road rehabilitation, including road repair, equipment for road repair works, labor-
based road and causeway restoration, and rehabilitation and reinstatement of 
bridges and depot facilities; 
 
(ii)  port rehabilitation, including wharf extension at Dili Port, restoration of the landing 
craft slipway at Dili Port, restoration of the container yard at Dili Port, and port 
repairs; 
 
(iii)  power sector rehabilitation, including rehabilitation of 15 power stations, and 
support to develop a power utility and its financial management system; and  
 
(iv)  project management services and training. 
 
C.  Implementation Performance 
1.  Road Rehabilitation 
29.  Road Rehabilitation. As of December 2001, the EIRP had tendered 66 road repair civil 
works contracts, of which 42 are complete and 24 in progress. Past contracts have addressed 
specific road closures by repairing slips, culvert failures, and drainage. The current and future 
contracts under the EIRP address backlog maintenance to the extent possible, in addition to 
ensuring access on the main road network. These contracts have generated 192,263 labor 
days, and restored 1,025 km of road drainage involving 259 villages. The 248 contractors were 
prequalified  under  a  capacity  classification  system  providing  a  foundation  for  a  contractor 
registry. Of the total 104 prequalified contractors, 95 are East Timorese.  
 
30.  Bridge Restoration. The EIRP conducted an emergency and a medium-term bridge 
condition survey covering all major bridge structures and the culverts. This resulted in a phased

V.  THE EMERGENCY INFRASTRUCTURE REHABILITATION PROJECT (PHASE 2) 
A.  Rationale 
53.  While  East  Timor  inherited  a  relatively  dense  and,  to  a  large  extent,  sealed  road 
network, road maintenance has been severely neglected. The inherent instability of the hilly 
topography, the vulnerability of the coastal network to flooding and river realignment, and the 
sensitivity  of  road  pavements  to  poor  drainage,  all  combine  to  make  a  high  maintenance 
network. The condition of the southern coastal road varies greatly: some sections are paved 
and are in good condition, while others are little more than tracks. The route crosses a number 
of large braided rivers with a combination of bridges and causeways. These causeways are 
vulnerable to the natural realignment of the waterways. The two major bridges, Punta Cassa 
and Zumalai, are incomplete. Five national and provincial north-south roads, all showing severe 
signs of neglect, provide vehicular access from Dili and the northern east-west road to the south

12 
coast. During the rainy season, rivers flood these roads and interrupt the transport system. Data 
on road conditions in East Timor demonstrate that a majority of district roads are in poor or very 
poor  condition,  and  that  a  strong  linkage  exists  between  road  network  conditions  and 
commercial activity. 
 
54.  The road network remains fragile. Under normal conditions, the network would require a 
high level of maintenance. However, in the past seven years maintenance has been neglected, 
and in the years following the Asian crises since 1997, halted. Recurrent maintenance of gravel 
roads is much more costly than that of paved roads, even taking due account of the different 
service  levels.  A  reduced  service  level  will  not  result  in  significant  savings  in  routine 
maintenance costs. For example, the budget required to maintain a two-day access to Maliana 
on a gravel surface is the same as that needed to maintain a half-day access using the present 
paved surface.  
 
55.  The  EIRP  has  implemented  road  repair  works  in  addition  to  its  port  and  power 
components. The road repair works have been invaluable in facilitating access to humanitarian 
aid and peace and security. However, these have addressed immediate road closures and have 
only partially been able to implement permanent engineering solutions that will reduce the 
maintenance burden in the long term. This program requires additional resources. The EIRP is 
also  supporting  longer-term  sector  development,  establishment  of  routine  maintenance 
mechanisms,  field  organization,  local  contracting  industry,  community  engagement,  and 
capacity  building  for  sector  management.  Accordingly,  the  additional  funding  will  focus  on 
intensifying and extending the EIRP objective to restore the road network to a condition in which 
its economic life can be extended effectively through routine maintenance within available 
recurrent funding levels. 
 
B.  Objectives  
56.  In light of the forecasted recurrent budgetary constraints of the emerging East Timor, 
the EIRP-2 will focus on stabilizing the road network and enabling it to be left in a condition from 
which it can be maintained with a relatively modest budget. The objective of the EIRP-2 is to 
support earthworks to diminish the annually recurring emergency requirement by reducing the 
backlog maintenance requirement. It will also continue programs initiated under the EIRP to 
establish a viable and efficient maintenance operation in East Timor and support technical 
preparation of the East Timorese maintenance service to carry out routine maintenance and 
contract village groups.

F.  Technical Approach  
1.  Civil Works to Reduce Emergency Maintenance Requirement 
60.  Earthworks. The earthworks rehabilitation will support the reconstruction and minor 
realignment of short road sections that have become unstable and have potential for technical 
correction. The soils, topography, and climate combined render the road network vulnerable to 
landslides. Clearing and repairing these is a major component of the recurrent maintenance 
activities. Annual repairs cannot effectively and economically reinstate the extensive landslip 
sites. More permanent solutions are required through improved alignment and fully engineered 
slope stabilization works and bioengineering techniques. This component will initiate a strategy 
for preventive civil works for bench16 failures that are currently absorbing an unacceptable 
proportion of the recurrent budget. A tentative list of roads, from which sections will be identified, 
is in Appendix 5.

61.  Bioengineering. Bioengineering techniques will be used to enhance slope stability. 
Under these techniques, indigenous plants will be identified that will effectively reduce soil 
moisture, resist surface erosion, and bind surfaces with strong and deep root systems. Once 
appropriate plants are identified, small nurseries will be established, and optimum planting and 
care strategies identified, demonstrated, and implemented. 
 
62.  Periodic Maintenance. Periodic maintenance requirements cost about $12 million per 
annum. This reinstates road surfaces damaged by traffic abrasion and wet season erosion. 
Most roads have lost the integrity of their wearing surfaces. Consequently, they deteriorate too 
rapidly for routine maintenance to be effective, and have become impassable in wet weather. 
While an ideal periodic maintenance program would resurface about one seventh of the network 
each year, periodic road resurfacing is required at intervals of 5 to 10 years. However, no such 
program has been implemented during the past four years, and as much as 60% of the network 
is overdue for resurfacing treatment. Sites needing work most urgently will be identified and this 
treatment strategy initiated. A small bridge replacement program will support the repair or 
replacement of substandard and vulnerable major drainage structures on the main roads. 
 
2.  Support to Establish a Routine Maintenance Regime

network environment. Under these conditions even minor slips and drain blockages result in 
road sections becoming impassible after heavy rainfall. Under the EIRP village groups are 
responsible  for  maintaining  the  road  drainage  system;  eventually,  funding  for  this  will  be 
transferred to recurrent budget of the Government. The EIRP-2 provide technical support to 
establish the community-based maintenance program and related technical capacity in the field 
organization.

3.  Description of the Environment 
 
12.  Many of the key features of East Timor’s environment are attributable to the fact that it is 
a small island: 
 
(i)  Natural  phenomena  including  seismic  activity  and  landslips  affect  a  greater 
proportion of the landmass. Landslips in East Timor are commonplace. 
(ii)  Water  catchment  areas  are  smaller  with  effects  of  erosion  on  them 
proportionately  higher.  Watershed  management  in  East  Timor  is  a  key 
environmental issue. 
(iii)  Coastal  regions  take  up  a  higher  percentage  of  the  land.  Coastal  zone 
management in East Timor is a key environmental issue.  
(iv)  The flora and fauna are more specialized, prone to suppression by the invasion 
of  exotic  species,  and  include  a  higher  proportion  of  endemic  species.  The 
incidence of occurrence of exotic plant and animal species in East Timor is high, 
while its biodiversity is an important economic asset: a diverse array of nontimber 
forest products are traditionally gathered and traded. 
(v)  Societies  have  developed  in  relative  isolation  with  relatively  stronger,  more 
distinctive cultures. Approximately 12 ethnic groups make up the indigenous 
population of East Timor. 
(vi)  The effects of immigration and emigration are more acutely felt.  
 
13.  East Timor’s environment is also dominated by precarious geological conditions, a moist 
climate, and a weak institutional base for environmental management.  
 
a.  Physical Resources 
 
i.  Topography and Geology 
 
14.  Steep hills and valleys dominate the terrain within East Timor, with the main feature 
being a mountain ridge running east-west across the island. The island itself is situated at the 
nexus of four geological plates and two continental blocks, and is formed by tectonic plate

Appendix 11  43
activity that resulted in a large sedimentary rock mass being lifted above sea level. Three units, 
distinguished by their age and origins, comprise the rock mass. The youngest of these, the 
sedimentary rock, dominates the top rock layers, while the underlying, older rock comprises 
schists, slates, and shales. The landscape is characterized by relative geological youth, the 
inherent instability of the sedimentary rock, and a high incidence of folds and faults. Because 
the island is relatively young, the uplift process that has formed it is still in progress, and is 
estimated to be taking place at a rate of 10 millimeter (mm) per year.2 
 
15.  The nature of the predominant, younger sedimentary rock is particularly relevant to the 
engineering of hill roads. These rocks feature conglomerates that are poorly consolidated, with 
weak matrices, as well as sandstone, siltstone, and weak alluvial deposits. These are variable in 
strength and texture, and prone to failure triggered by the ongoing uplift process or torrential 
rain, quite apart from those caused by earthworks or agriculture.  
 
ii.  Climate 
 
16.   East Timor’s climate is largely warm and moist, with considerable variations occurring 
with  altitude  and  the  influence  of  the  mountain  chain  on  the  distribution  of  rainfall.  Mean 
temperatures vary from around 28ºC at sea level to around 19ºC at the highest settlements, 
some 1,400 meters above sea level. The seasons are quite even, and diurnal temperatures vary 
more than mean monthly temperatures.  
 
17.  The mountain chain intercepts precipitation, resulting in a drier zone on its northern side, 
with a wet season of some 4 to 6 months commencing around November, while the land to the 
south  experiences  two  wet  seasons,  a  major  one  of  7  to  9  months  commencing  around 
November, and an additional, briefer one, between May and August. Significantly, much of the 
rain falls in brief, torrential falls, creating periods of intense hazard to property, agriculture, and 
infrastructure from saturated soils and rapid surface water flows.  
 
b.  Ecological Resources 
 
18.  Documented knowledge on the plants and animals, and their original communities in 
East Timor, is relatively limited, although current research on East Timor’s ecosystems suggests 
that much local knowledge is undocumented. Little is therefore known about the value, in 
economic or conservation terms, of natural resources on the island, particularly about the uses 
and properties of indigenous and even endemic plant and animal species. However, there are 
signs that East Timor bears a diverse and unique natural resource base: Field workers within 
the current Government system report a high level of knowledge of uses of plants for medicinal 
and other purposes. The basic geology of East Timor differs from that of its neighbors and is 
therefore likely to have evolved a significantly different flora and fauna. In addition, the entire 
region, where land masses have been brought together by tectonic plate movements, is of 
intense biogeographical interest. 
 
19.  The lack of knowledge extends to the national park and protected areas that have been 
established in East Timor. The law that existed under previous the Indonesian regime named 15 
protected areas. Under UNTAET, these areas were protected in Regulation No. 2000/19 of 30 
June  2000,  which  also  gave  UNTAET  broader  powers  for  the  protection  of  species  and 
reserves. Accurate and reliable data as to the boundaries of the protected areas is not available,

i.  Vegetation 
 
20.  The present day vegetation cover is largely influenced by agriculture, land clearance, 
and grass burning. Throughout much of the island, particularly along the north coast, hillsides 
bear  mainly  grassland  savanna,  with  a  sparse  overstory  of  trees  such  as  Eucalyptus  sp, 
extensive grass growth, a limited shrub story, and an absence of young tree saplings in most 
places. More diverse growth occurs on steep stream banks and clefts within the hill landscape. 
Where the vegetation is less disturbed by human settlement, a range of forest types occur 
mainly reflecting the rainfall distribution patterns. In driest areas to the north of the island, thorn 
forest occurs, giving way to dry deciduous forest in much of the coastal land. Mountain areas 
feature  moist  deciduous  forest,  with  evergreen  rainforest  occurring  in  pockets.  Roadside 
vegetation, particularly in the northern part of the island, features a high level of invasion by 
aggressive exotic weed species, e.g, Tithonia diversifolia and Lantana camara, both common 
noxious weed species with an extremely wide distribution. 
 
ii.  Fauna 
 
21.  The island’s fauna includes both indigenous and introduced species. The main threat to 
the populations of indigenous species, is the loss of the habitat in which they evolved. Extensive 
conversion of forestland since early colonial occupation has therefore resulted in reductions of 
the  populations  of  indigenous  fauna  species.  Introduced  animals  include  deer,  civets,  and 
rodents; a number of Australian bird species have also been introduced.  
 
22.  A number of rare species of interest occur among the island’s mammal, bird, insect, and 
fish populations. The scientific interest in the fauna of East Timor and its island neighbors, 
although little studied, is intensified by the fact that two major biogeographical regions, Oriental 
and Australian, meet in the region. Separated during early geological time, the two regions 
developed quite distinct fauna. Although the fauna are understood to have merged, in terms of 
species composition, as the two regions came together, significant differences continue to be 
observed.  
 
c.  Marine Ecosystems 
 
23.  A number of marine ecosystems can be found around the immediate coast of East 
Timor, namely coral reefs and seagrass beds, with mangrove forests, rocky sea bottoms, and 
muddy flats in the intertidal zone. While a significant fishing industry has never developed in the 
country, these ecosystems are of considerable scientific and conservation value. Many of the 
creatures of such ecosystems are vulnerable to changes in water turbidity caused by sediment 
deposition.  
 
d.  Human and Economic Development 
 
24.  The status of human and economic development in East Timor has largely been shaped 
by Portuguese colonization, between 1562 and 1974, and also by the ensuing Indonesian 
occupation until late 1999. Early Portuguese colonists established trade in commodities such as 
sandalwood, timber, honey, and beeswax. Consistent with the actions of many colonial powers

Appendix 11  45
of the period, little effort was made to curb overexploitation and reserves of sandalwood and 
possibly certain timber species were brought to near extinction by the early 1900s. During the 
four centuries of Portuguese colonization, Catholicism became the dominant religion, and a 
colonial system of administration was established. The Portuguese colonial period ended in 
1974,  and  the  Indonesian  government  took  power  following  an  invasion  in  1975.  While 
Indonesia invested in the nation’s infrastructure, much of this appears to have been for the 
purpose of countering local resistance to their occupation. To facilitate the control of resistance 
among tribal groups, particularly in remote areas, the Indonesian government built an extensive 
road network, and allegedly imposed migration of tribal people within East Timor so as to 
fragment traditional group structures and weaken resistance. The Indonesian occupation came 
to an end in late 1999 when a referendum demonstrated that most East Timorese wanted 
complete  independence  from  Indonesia.  This  result  triggered  intense  violence  that  led  to 
numerous  deaths,  and  the  decimation  of  the  country’s  infrastructure  and  services,  with 
widespread destruction of public buildings and utilities as well as private homes. With the 
installation of UNTAET in September 1999, an emergency rehabilitation effort has ensued, 
focusing primarily on restoring infrastructure required to distribute humanitarian aid and on 
redeveloping durable infrastructure and the capacity for its maintenance. As of 20 May 2002, 
UNTAET has handed the administration over to an indigenous Government and a reduced 
United Nations Mission in East Timor has been agreed to be retained to ensure inability and 
political stability of East Timor. 
 
25.  East Timor has always been poor and was one of the poorest parts of Indonesia, itself a 
poor country. Indonesia’s own economic performance was influenced by the Asian financial 
crisis in the late 1990s, which, with the fall of the rupiah, led to very low incomes for East 
Timorese people prior to 1999. Coupled with inflation, the Asian crisis caused severe poverty. 
As a result of post referendum violence, some 24 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) may 
have been lost in 1999.3 
 
26.  Efforts to gather economic, demographic, and other information of key importance to the 
design and implementation of development programs in East Timor are currently under way, 
and include the World Bank-managed Community Empowerment and Local Governance Project

largely inaccurate.  
 
27.  The population of East Timor is approximately 800,000, which includes refugee groups 
living in West Timor, nearly all of whom are in the process of returning to East Timor.

36.  One very important aspect of the principle of best practice is the issue of side tipping of 
spoil material. Although widespread in hilly areas throughout Asia, the practice of side tipping of 
excavated  material  or  landslip  material  is  extremely  damaging.  Loose  spoil  deposited  on 
hillsides rapidly forms rills and gullies, which concentrate runoff water causing gullies to expand 
and cut into the original ground. The effect is made worse by the smothering of vegetation, 
which plays an important part in slope protection and stabilization. As it travels downstream, the 
spoil increases sediment load and erosive power of waterways, potentially damaging aquatic 
ecosystems and agriculture as well.  
 
37.  The effects of side tipping can be mitigated against by ensuring that all loose material 
arising from excavations or from the clearance of landslips is transported to safe tip sites where 
it can be retained, and even used as a productive growing medium. The total cost of mitigation 
for the EIRP-2 is tentatively estimated, in part II of this report at under $50,000. This represents 
a  very  minor  addition  to  the  project  cost.  In  the  long  term,  the  institution  of  good  spoil 
management will set high national standards, for which, at present, there is little precedent in 
Asia.

44.  This evaluation of environmental impacts of the EIRP-2 was carried out using quantity, 
cost,  and  price  estimates  relating  to  environmental  impacts,  supplemented  by  qualitative 
assessments. The purpose of the valuation of environmental effects is to 
 
(i)  input environmental benefits and costs in to the benefit-cost analysis for the 
EIRP-2. 
(ii)  assess the effect of proposed mitigation on project cost 
(iii)  arrive at a net environmental cost or benefit for the EIRP-2. 
 
2.  Screening of Impacts 
 
45.  In accordance with ADB guidelines,7 each impact identified in the screening process for 
the environmental assessment was screened using the following rationale: 
 
(i)  Impacts judged to be very small were excluded, with reasons, from quantitative 
assessment. 
(ii)  Impacts  for  which  a  high  degree  of  uncertainty  exists  as  to  their  governing 
parameters were described qualitatively and quantitatively to the extent feasible. 
(iii)  Impacts  whose  effects  may  be  valued  were  assessed  using  an  appropriate 
method. 
(iv)  In the case of impacts that were judged to be mitigated, the costs of mitigation 
measures  were  estimated,  and  the  expected  impacts  that  may  occur  in  the

increased  populations  of  indigenous  plants,  resulting  from  their  use  for

3.  Valuation of Impacts 
 
47.  The EIRP-2 targets to control of major and minor slope failure hazards to minimize their 
effect on the integrity of the transport network and the environment as a whole. The valuation of 
benefits  is  based  on  the  expected  quantities  and  values  associated  with  the  with-project 
scenario,  compared  with  the  expected  environmental  consequences  of  the  without-project 
scenario. For the with-project scenario, under which no special attention is expected to be given 
to preventing slope failures, uncertainty exists as to the precise scale and frequency of slope 
failures, the level of resources and effectiveness of preventative measures available, and the 
quantity  and  nature  of  environmental  damage  caused  by  stressors  such  as  landslide  slip 
material. This valuation exercise compares and contrasts the anticipated environmental benefits 
and costs using both qualitative and quantitative estimates. The approach taken is therefore to 
evaluate project benefits mainly qualitatively, to estimate the cost of mitigation of adverse 
environmental impacts that would arise as a result of the EIRP-2, and to quantify any residual 
negative  environmental  impacts  as  far  as  possible.  To  estimate  mitigation  costs,  a  set  of 
assumptions for locations and quantities of project work has been made. These are summarized 
in para. 87 of this appendix. 
 
a.  Beneficial Impacts 
 
i.  Effects of Improved Slope Stability at Landslide Hazard Areas 
Following Construction 
 
48.  As a result of the severe geological conditions of the island, described in paras. 14-15 of 
this  appendix  potential  landslide  sites  are  numerous,  and  variable  in  scale.  The  technical 
challenges  involved  in  identifying  incipient  landslide  sites  and  developing  appropriate 
engineering solutions based on site investigations and soil tests, will allow a large number of 
such sites to be effectively treated by using geotechnical engineering measures such as the 
construction of retaining and revetment structures. The scope of works extends to the use of 
bioengineering techniques to enhance the effectiveness of structures and treat smaller risk 
sites. The project works are therefore expected to reduce the costs of maintaining the road 
network through early and effective treatment of existing and potential hazard sites.  
 
49.  The direct environmental benefit envisaged from this work is the protection of land that is 
at risk to damage from landslides. This is highly significant. In addition, there are indirect 
benefits  associated  with  the  retention  of  material  that  would  otherwise  be  released  into 
watersheds  as  a  result  of  the  landslides.  These  include  the  prevention  of  damage  to 
ecosystems,  and  agricultural  and  residential  land  through  sediment  transport  in  flood  and 
stream flows; and the effects on marine ecosystems of the release of soil particles into the sea.  
 
50.  The receptors of soil and rock debris from landslides are terrestrial ecosystems, marine 
ecosystems,  farms,  and  homes.  In  view  of  the  occurrence  of  naturally  occurring  landslips

terrestrial and marine, have likely evolved under conditions of repeated deposition of soil and 
rock debris produced by landslides. In view of this, no significant impact on receptor ecosystems

51.  In the case of both farms and homes, severe risks are associated with occasional 
landslide events. Potentially severe landslide areas will likely be successfully treated under the 
EIRP-2. Any single successful treatment of a potential landslide is likely to prevent catastrophic 
loss of productive land and homes downstream. The effects on both agricultural productivity and 
private homes is therefore highly significant. While the location and extent of damage to land 
and property cannot be reliably predicted, the cost of road reinstatement alone following such 
an event is likely to exceed $100,000. The environmental cost is therefore rated as highly 
significant. 
 
ii.  Effects of Improved Routine Maintenance 
 
52.  Under the EIRP-2, a routine maintenance regime will be established that will seek to 
involve communities in organizing and carrying out routine maintenance work. Such a regime 
will  potentially  result  in  improved  vigilance  and  more  rapid  corrective  action  for  incipient 
problems such as drain blockages, undercutting of retaining walls, and pot-hole development. 
This rapid corrective action to incipient problems will lower the incidence of larger problems 
such  as  gully  formation  and  the  scouring  out  of  structures.  Besides  reducing  the  cost  of 
maintenance of the road network, this will also result in reductions in the release of spoil into 
watersheds. The impact on agricultural productivity and rural homes is rated as significant. The 
increased cost of repair to the road in the absence of an efficient maintenance system may be 
high in the medium and long term, in the order of $10,000 to $100,000.

58.  Assuming terrestrial and marine ecosystems have evolved under conditions where such

supporting the slope. The material rapidly forms rills and gullies, which cut into the slopes, often

INTIAL SOCIAL AND POVERTY ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (Phase 2) (EIRP-2) will follow the 
existing Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (EIRP), being implemented under Grant 
8181-ETM.  It  will  address  key  concerns  for  establishing  an  effective  road  maintenance 
capability in East Timor, by undertaking slope stabilization tasks on critical landslide hazard 
sites  within  the  road  network,  and  provide  support  for  the  establishment  of  a  routine 
maintenance regime, focusing on community involvement. 
 
2.  The purpose of this report is to summarize the approach and findings of a social and 
poverty assessment of the EIRP-2, conducted during April 2001. The investigations consisted of 
key informant interviews, questionnaire surveys of the principal beneficiary groups, and review 
of secondary information sources. In addition, semiformal meetings were held with beneficiary 
groups to obtain opinions, views, and wishes of key stakeholders for use in project design.  
 
B.  Project Description 
 
3.  The  EIRP-2  is  an  infrastructure  development  initiative  and  will  consist  of  slope 
stabilization works on critical landslide hazard sites within East Timor’s road network, capacity 
building in terms of technical assistance (TA) for the establishment of a community labor-based 
routine maintenance regime, training of East Timorese counterparts, and project management. 
Project sites are located on selected priority road links throughout East Timor, comprising the 
road lengths between Batugade and Zumalai in Bobonaro and Cova Lima districts in the west of 
the country, Tibar to Ermera in Liquica and Ermera districts to the west of Dili, and Baucau to 
Viqueque towns in Baucau and Viqueque districts toward the east of the country. The total road 
length covered is 211.4 kilometers (km), and total EIRP-2 cost is estimated at $10 million. 
 
4.  The need for the EIRP-2 arises from both the key role of road access in extending 
services and market access to the rural poor of East Timor, and the difficulties encountered in 
maintaining roads at reasonable cost in the severe geological conditions prevalent on the island. 
The population of East Timor is largely rural, and limitations on access to schools, hospitals and 
markets both exacerbate poor living conditions and limit opportunities for poverty eradication. 
The reliability of road access is limited by the frequency of landslide occurrence, which is largely 
due to the weak materials of which most slopes are composed, and high, concentrated rainfall 
rendering much of the primary road network highly vulnerable to failure. The expense and 
technical  difficulty  involved  in  repairing  and  preventing  landslides  threatens  to  deflect  vital 
resources from routine road repair and maintenance over primary and secondary roads, which 
is essential if vehicle operating costs, and hence accessibility of roads to use by poorer groups, 
are to decrease. The strategy adopted for the EIRP-2 is to address critical areas of instability 
within the network, to establish an efficient routine maintenance regime that itself contributes to 
the reduction of rural poverty, along with capacity building to help the future roads authority 
acquire the necessary managerial and technical skills. 
 
5.  The establishment of a community-based routine road maintenance regime is of special 
relevance to the social and poverty assessment, as a specific pro-poor aspect of the project 
design.

C.  Country Background 
 
1.  Social Issues 
 
9.  East Timor is currently in a postconflict situation, following the events associated with a 
referendum held in late 1999, in which the people of East Timor voted overwhelmingly in favor 
of independence from Indonesia. The referendum prompted widespread and severe violence 
that resulted in many deaths, the destruction of public infrastructure and private property, and 
the  loss  of  many  skilled  and  professional  people.  However,  the  referendum  succeeded  in 
removing the former administration, which had become intensely unpopular with the majority of 
East Timorese.  
 
10.  The current transition period and forthcoming elections offer both opportunities and 
challenges. The new leaders who are to be elected in 2001 have the opportunity to benefit from 
the lessons learned by other Asian and Pacific countries who have experienced significant 
structural changes in government in recent decades. In addition, the lessons learned from 
varying approaches to social and economic development in developing countries can also be 
brought into consideration as the new government forms strategies for the development of the 
new nation. At the same time, most East Timorese have high expectations from the new 
government, while real improvements for the majority of East Timorese will take time to achieve. 
In addition, the country’s new leaders will be elected from a group that has been denied the 
benefit of experience in governance during the former regime. 
 
2.  Poverty Issues 
 
11.  Poverty in East Timor is, at present, very widespread, particularly in rural areas. While 
many of the rural poor are able to avoid severe food shortages, daily expenses such as 
transportation and essential goods are high, and opportunities for income generation limited. 
According to available data,1 some 75 percent of the population are poor; their average income 
is some 7 percent below the poverty line. Measures of inequality currently suggest limited 
disparity between the relatively well off and the poor. 
 
12.  Poverty has always been widespread in East Timor, but has been exacerbated both by 
the events of late 1999, and by a preceding period of deepening neglect of social and other 
infrastructure by the previous government.  
 
13.  Though security was restored by mid 2000 and some public services set up by the East 
Timor Transitional Administration (ETTA), the effects of the violence and destruction, which 
included the removal of access to Indonesian domestic markets, combined with the period of 
neglect by the previous government, led to a considerably worsened poverty situation.  
 
14.  In comparison with the situation prior to the referendum, the rural poor of East Timor 
suffer from higher costs of transportation and essential goods such as clothing and fuel. Many 
are living in damaged houses, or in crowded conditions as a result of the destruction of private 
homes. While the ETTA has reestablished many schools and set up health services, both of 
these services are relatively understaffed. Health conditions appear to be deteriorating, with a

small businesses or seek employment further afield. 
 
15.  Reduced export opportunities and increasing migration to the towns from the countryside 
has resulted in growing urban poverty, particularly in Dili. The urban poor share with their rural 
neighbors the situation of worsening health, limited education, and limited opportunities. 
 
16.  Potential  for  economic  growth  exists  through  agricultural  crop  development,  the 
sustainable exploitation of assets such as oil and gas reserves, and tourism. As improved 
governance  evolves  in  East  Timor  and  strategies  for  economic  growth  are  identified  and 
implemented,  the  distribution  of  wealth  will  remain  a  challenge.  A  significant  means  of 
empowering groups such as the rural poor to take part in growing economic activity is the 
encouragement of activities that involve sustainable cash incomes to the poorest members of 
Timorese society, which empowers people with the ability to establish small businesses, search 
for work opportunities, and have improved access to the media.

number of villagers were employed by the former Department of Infrastructure, or occasionally 
by contractors, in road maintenance tasks. A number of villagers have relevant skills such as 
plant operators, mechanics, masons, and site supervisors.

F.  Project Design Options 
 
1.  Options for Increasing Poverty Impact 
 
56.  The  poverty  impact  assessment  identifies  that  the  shortage  of  income-earning 
opportunities is a major concern among villagers in the project area. The shortage of cash in 
village economies further reduces the ability of villagers to establish small businesses and 
acquire skills to bring them out of poverty.  
 
57.  The  establishment  of  a  community-based  road  maintenance  regime  provides  a 
mechanism for providing cash to rural poor communities, as well as the means to raise the 
incomes of beneficiaries above the poverty line. 
 
2.  Gender 
 
58.  Responses by beneficiaries in the project area have shown that physical work and the 
control of funds are generally undertaken by men. These views were corroborated during village 
meetings with groups of beneficiaries, although in most cases villagers said that women were 
regularly involved in tasks such as vegetation clearance. The fact that women are likely to have 
a relatively small share of employment and the allocation of the proceeds of employment is 
significant.  
 
59.  Three  percent  of  households  interviewed  were  headed  by  women.  The  possible 
exclusion of such households from access to paid work on road maintenance is an issue of 
concern.  
 
60.  To ensure that women are not denied the benefits of access to paid employment, it is 
recommended that the issue be discussed with village representatives when forming contracts 
for labor, and the representatives should agree to ensure that women are fully entitled to 
employment. The situation should be monitored when community labor contracts are being 
implemented. A sample of women within the community should be interviewed prior to the 
renewal of contracts. 
 
3.  Participation 
 
61.  The establishment of a community-based road maintenance regime, which is a major 
component of the EIRP-2, is participatory in nature. The views of communities have been 
obtained  in  developing  the  project  concept,  through  small-scale  meetings  held  at  sample

villages along the alignment of both roads. The majority view is that community-based labor 
should be organized by means of contracts, arranged through elected village representatives.  
 
4.  Governance 
 
62.  East  Timor  is  in  the  process  of  forming  an  indigenous  government.  This  situation 
provides the opportunity to introduce concepts that have evolved from lessons learned through 
development endeavors elsewhere in Asia. The EIRP-2, as a strategically designed sustainable 
maintenance initiative, will put forward a strategy for management of the road sector that 
embodies the principles of equitability and justice.  
 
5.  Affordability 
 
63.  The use of project funds to address critical landslide hazard areas and reduce their 
impact on future road maintenance funds is an initiative designed specifically for the issue of 
affordability, as is the establishment of a community-based road maintenance regime.  
 
64.  With regard to continued sustainability of the road maintenance system that will be 
established, the rate of pay to villagers is a critical issue.  
 
6.  Labor 
 
65.  The  EIRP-2  makes  use  of  labor  intensive  construction  and  road  maintenance 
techniques. 
 
7.  Other Risks/Vulnerabilities 
 
66.  East Timor is in a postconflict situation, and has emerged from a recent period in which 
intense violence was commonplace. With the withdrawal of the United Nations Transitional 
Administration in East Timor and peacekeeping forces following the formation of a new elected 
government, a period will ensue in which poverty levels will remain high, expectations on the 
performance of the new government will be high, and difficulties likely as the new nation is 
formed. Localized conflict and violence, and periods of political unrest are possible. 
 
67.  A further risk concerns the difference in capability among neighboring communities. 
Inevitably some communities are better organized and more capable of undertaking road work 
than others. At the same time, the village meetings and existing experience show that most rural 
communities in East Timor do not allow people from outside the community to undertake work in 
their village areas. This will lead to difficulties in the case of communities that do not perform, as 
communities that do not carry out road maintenance work satisfactorily are likely to resist the 
engagement of workers from outside the community to complete the work. Strong skill and 
judgment by road authorities is required to overcome this risk. 
 
G.  Conclusion 
 
68.  Positive  and  significant  impacts  of  the  EIRP-2  are  anticipated  for  the  beneficiary 
communities.  The  civil  works  component  will  enhance  the  reliability  of  road  access  for 
communities  around  the  country,  including  poorer  and  more  vulnerable  communities.  The 
establishment of a community-based road maintenance regime will provide a cost-effective 
means of ensuring that roads are maintained, and a mechanism for providing sustainable 
incomes to rural communities that have a strong need for income-generating opportunities.
